item.title:
R to @letsgetonchain: Question for such a user onboarding flow.
The first step is still to create an EOA wallet and the first action then is to sign the eip 7702 authorization to a delegated smart contract that verifies Secp256r1 signature.
Thereafter the user can do anything he wants with his touch id, no eoa private key needed.
Do hot wallets even need to store the eoa's private key thereafter or can they just remove it after the user has exported it ?

item.title:
R to @letsgetonchain: When each call completes, it returns a result to the caller (the floor below) leading the sky scraper to bubble down eventually to the ground floor and thereby completing the transaction.
This sky scraper (call stack) is limited to 1024 floors (frames).
item.dc:creator: @letsgetonchain

item.title:
R to @letsgetonchain: That frame then gets executed via the run() method from revm's Execution Handler.
Each frame can spawn new frames through EVM instructions like CALL, STATICCALL, DELEGATECALL, or CREATE / CREATE2. Think of a new frame in the context of the sky scraper as a new floor.

item.title:
Came across EIP-2930 access lists in revm.
These lists allow tx to specify addresses/storage slots they will use.
Making use of them reduces gas costs:
Cold addr: 2600 Access list addr: 2400
Cold storage: 2100 Access list storage: 1900
Are most dapps using these?

item.title:
Been a solidity dev for the last three years and thus aware of the 24 kb limit for runtime contract size.
Didn't know that there was a limit on the init code as well of two times that, 48kb.
You only get a full picture of the evm by going through its implementation line by line
